newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU soft drinks industry calls for cheaper sugar.
newsitem.headline: EU soft drinks industry calls for cheaper sugar.

text.p: European soft drinks producers on Friday urged EU farm ministers to also consider sugar price-cutting reforms when they discuss future dairy policy at an informal meeting in Middelburg, Netherlands, on Sunday.
The European Commission in a recent long-term study said the EU's growing sugar surplus would increase with the membership of east European countries.
Part of the surplus could be absorbed by the soft drinks industry if sugar was reasonably priced, according to the Union of EC Soft Drinks Associations (UNESDA).
"The current support system, which is production-based, encourages inefficient sugar output at huge cost to consumers and industrial sugar users," said Alain Beaumont, UNESDA Secretary General.
Beaumont said in a statement an efficient system should be based on direct income support, completely decoupled from production.
"This would ensure an adequate revenue for sugar beet farmers in a regime which operates according to market forces," he added.
UNESDA members, who employ some 100,000 people in the EU, are significant users of sugar, glucose syrup and fructose.
